name: Post Malone
description:
'''Austin Richard Post''' (born July 4, 1995), known professionally as '''Post Malone''', is an American rapper, singer, songwriter, record producer, and actor. His music blends various genres including [[hip-hop]], [[Pop music|pop]], [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[Trap music|trap]], and [[Country music|country]]. His [[stage name]] was created when he put his birth name into a rap name generator.

He began his musical career in 2011, and began to gain recognition with his 2015 debut single "[[White Iverson]]", which peaked at number 14 on the U.S. [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. He then signed with [[Republic Records]] and then released his debut studio album ''[[Stoney (album)|Stoney]]'' (2016), which peaked at number four on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and included the [[RIAA certification|diamond]]-certified single "[[Congratulations (Post Malone song)|Congratulations]]" (featuring [[Quavo]]). His second album, ''[[Beerbongs & Bentleys]]'' (2018), debuted atop the ''Billboard'' 200 and set numerous [[Streaming media|streaming]] records. It contained the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 number-one singles "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]" (featuring [[21 Savage]]) and "[[Psycho (Post Malone song)|Psycho]]" (featuring [[Ty Dolla Sign]]), and was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]] at the [[61st Annual Grammy Awards|61st Grammy Awards]]. His third ''Billboard'' Hot 100 number-one single, "[[Sunflower (Post Malone and Swae Lee song)|Sunflower]]", a duet with [[Swae Lee]], was released for [[Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse (soundtrack)|the accompanying soundtrack]] to the 2018 animated film ''[[Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse]]''; it became the highest certified song in [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] history and it was the first to receive [[RIAA certification|double diamond]] (20-times platinum) certification.

"Sunflower" was also included on his third album, ''[[Hollywood's Bleeding]]'' (2019), which became his second to peak atop the ''Billboard'' 200 and received his second nomination for Album of the Year at the [[63rd Annual Grammy Awards|63rd Grammy Awards]]. It spawned the single "[[Circles (Post Malone song)|Circles]]", which became his fourth number one hit on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, and spent 61 weeks on the chart, becoming his biggest hit single to date. His fourth and fifth albums, ''[[Twelve Carat Toothache]]'' (2022) and [[Austin (album)|''Austin'']] (2023), both peaked at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200 and saw continued success; the former spawned the top ten singles "[[I Like You (A Happier Song)]]" (featuring [[Doja Cat]]) and "[[One Right Now]]" (with [[the Weeknd]]), while the latter explored [[pop rock]] and spawned the top 15 single, "[[Chemical (Post Malone song)|Chemical]]". Two of his 2024 singles debuted atop the ''Billboard'' Hot 100: his guest appearance on [[Taylor Swift]]'s "[[Fortnight (song)|Fortnight]]", and his first [[country pop]] song, "[[I Had Some Help]]", with the country singer [[Morgan Wallen]]). The latter served as the lead single of his sixth album, ''[[F-1 Trillion]]'' (2024), which further experimented with the genre and became his third non-consecutive number-one album on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].

Malone is among the [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music artists]], with over 80 million records sold. His [[List of awards and nominations received by Post Malone|accolades]] include eleven [[Billboard Music Award|''Billboard'' Music Awards]], five [[American Music Awards]], six [[MTV Video Music Awards]], and eighteen [[Grammy Award]] nominations. He holds several ''Billboard'' chart records: He is the first solo lead artist to top both the [[Rap Airplay]] and [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Adult Contemporary]] charts, while "[[Circles (Post Malone song)|Circles]]" set the record for longest climb to number one (41 weeks) on the [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Adult Contemporary chart]] by a solo artist. As of {{currentyear}}, Malone holds the record for the artist with the most diamond-certified songs, with nine to his name.
